author: sky.cactus
content: I believe this has already been answered, but I have forgotten (sadly): Can I deposit and withdraw-to an ETH1 contract wallet?

author: sky.cactus
content: I know I'll need a secp256k1 private key for validator signatures, which IIUC cannot be rolled/changed (which makes me very sad).  Assuming I can deposit/withdraw from a contract wallet, do I need any other private keys to be a validator besides that?

author: sproul
content: It's in the process of being supported now via https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/pull/2149

author: sproul
content: The (fixed) voting key is the only key you'll need to be a validator (apart from your withdrawal address). It's a BLS12-381 key though, rather than a secp256k1 key

author: sky.cactus
content: Today I only need a single BLS12-381 key (validator key), or after that linked PR is merged and implemented that is all I will need?

author: sproul
content: Right now you also need a BLS withdrawal key

author: sproul
content: but it can be kept in cold storage

author: sproul
content: Once that PR is merged you can use an Eth1 address+key in place of a BLS withdrawal key

author: sky.cactus
content: Is there any chance that validator key rotation will be added prior to Phase 1?

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., a way for the withdraw address to post a transaction to Ethereum mainnet that changes the validator public key that is allowed to sign validations.

author: sproul
content: I guess it could be, but there's no design fleshed out (not even an issue on the eth2.0 specs repo AFAICT)
